job_title: Clinical Development Specialist in Atlanta, GA
pros: Close to home, pension, opportunities.
cons: Not up to date with technology. Why are we rolling around dinamaps and computers instead of having them in each room? They just rolled out VC-150 which is uploading vital signs to the EMR in real time with one click instead of the person doing the vital signs entering it manually. I’m glad it was done finally as this gave the staff back more time to do other things for the patient hence improving our patient experience. Many other hospitals have had this in place for years. There is still so much paper documentation required which is time consuming and frustrating for staff and the Cerner charting system they use needs an upgrade to EPIC. So many redundancies, time to load charts for patients with extended stay with individual clicks on banner bars, several places to chart for the same thing which creates low compliance in documentation. Staff confused where to chart certain times. IS is under equipment and then another section for IS, SCD are under equipment and ADL’s etc. Adult education section is too busy, instead of just one heading for quality measures and another for misc. then a list opening only specific ones necessary for the patient. Collecting data is cumbersome due to the emr system.

pros: Northside Hospital is by far the best healthcare system I have ever worked for. Additionally, their focus on quality and investing resources where needed are unmatched. Not only am I proud to work as a Northside employee, but I would take my family to a Northside facility should they have a medical need (even when I worked for other HC systems-I'd still go to Northside Hospital!). Having compared Northside to other large healthcare systems has given me great perspective. The pay is fair, benefits are great (lots of discounts as well as a pension and 403B!), and there has NEVER been a time while working for Northside that I have felt pressured to do more with less or have had to deviate from what I know is safe due to resource restrictions. We have the equipment and staff that we need to do an exceptional job. Our campus is beautiful, and I thoroughly enjoy coming to work. We work hard but also have a lot of fun. I'm thankful to have had an opportunity to return to the organization. This is my HOME!
cons: Pay is not always the highest in terms of $/hr but they do have some great benefits to offset not being the highest paying. Northside is a conservative organization so many changes take longer than wanted at times due to the vetting process.

The ones that I enjoyed working for, were the ones that invest quality time and resources in their staff. pros: Maternal/infant and women’s services are top notch. You will see clinical situations not see at smaller, rural hospitals. Northside Hospital is nationally known maternity and women’s services. This is great because hospitals everywhere will hire you with solid experience from Northside. It’s also a pretty diverse hospital even though it’s in Sandy Springs. With 2-5 years experience in Women’s Services you can work anywhere. The hospital is fiscally responsible.
cons:
Very fast-paced. This is shocking to lots of nurse’s because women’s services are usually considered “easier” than traditional med-surg positions. While the acuity and patient ratios are lower overall, the number of deliveries and services offered for pregnancy, birth and general women’s health create a fast-paced environment and higher acuity maternal, women, and infant units in comparison to Northside Hospital. 
Lots of “catty & cliquish” behavior among nurses. The patients aren’t always as appreciative as those who are underserved. Their Nurse’s Week is horrible because the fiscal responsibility sometimes turns into just being down right cheap. They tend to promote from within first. You could possibly be passed over for a position b/c they’d rather have nurse that Northside trained even if he/she has less experience. So an experienced nurse that comes into Northside with experience may very well be overlooked for promotion and growth because the less experienced nurse interned and started with Northside & only has Northside experience. If you quit without notice that’s it…you’re ineligible for rehire at ALL NORTHSIDE FACILITIES!

pros: They offer a pension plan and 403b
cons:
Short patient time slots . Scheduled patients can walk in with orders that are sometimes wrong (because scheduling doesn’t require an order before scheduling patients) . You use up your whole scan time fixing it, and getting the MD to fax a new order, then you’re late for all the angry patients after, requiring you to work through lunches that you already get automatically docked for. So you are working a half an hour for free. Patients can come in as late as they want and you still have to take them, making your whole day late again with angry patients. Not enough time to clean properly between patients. Too much paperwork. No ergonomics or wrist, shoulder, arm rest between patients. 
Terrible health benefits. Unbelievably bad considering you are working for a hospital system.
Northside can make the time slots as small as they want, but it just means that techs aren’t following protocol and they are skipping images, sometimes missing pathology, in order to keep up and keep from being reprimanded about time. Is that really what’s best for the patient, and is it fair for your techs to risk their licenses and registries to rush, because money is the most important thing to Northside ?

job_title: Labor and Delivery RN in Atlanta, GA
pros: Northside Labor and Delivery deserves its name for being the “baby factory” and I truly believe we do it very well. I believe the interdisciplinary communication between anesthesia, OBs, RNs, techs, etc is incredible and so essential with how big our unit is. There is a mutual respect for one another and each role they play in the delivery process! I think that our charge nurses, team leaders and shift nurses do a great job in knowing what is going on with each patient in each room. I also believe that it really is a great place to learn and I know I will always have support and help when I need it with patient care.
cons: Northside labor and delivery is notorious for being the “baby factory” but it also is notorious for having extremely high turn over rates. I think new nurses are quickly burnt out with the night shift hours, weekend shifts, limited call outs, and stressful pace of the unit. I do not think we get enough support from our scheduler and manager in terms of time off. I believe that northside Lahr and delivery should make it easier for night shift nurses to move to day shift, make vacation weeks easier to schedule, and add more call outs. Our job is stressful and I believe more time for self care is essential and would play a huge role in improving our retention rate.

pros: Northside overall is a great company to work for. The benefits are awesome and there is always room for growth.
cons: The Patient Access Department is horrible. They will tell you on the interview that there is room for growth and that you will receive bonuses etc. There is no room for growth and that department. They pick and choose who they want to advance no matter how much effort or work you do. They prefer to advance people from the outside in positions instead of hiring within. Not to mention the bonuses story is a lie. The only people who see a good bonus on their paychecks are management. I've worked in Patient Access/Revenue Cylce For 10 + Years. I have never seen any department ran this way. It really explains why they can't keep employees.

job_title: Staff RN III in Lawrenceville, GA
pros: I enjoy the people I work with. We look out for each other and work well together. The differentials seem to be competitive as compared to other local hospitals (at least Northside's differentials are better than what GMC's was). They really do try to maintain appropriate RN to patient ratios in our dept.
cons: I can't speak for other departments but the one I'm in, there is a mass exodus. We have been bleeding for what seems like a while (at least a year, if not more). I'm still waiting it out to see if it gets better (trying to differentiate if it's because of the pandemic or the takeover and harmonization of policies as GMC has been taken over by Northside), but many have moved on to other areas. The culture of the dept encourages being worked to the bone. It doesn't feel like there is much support from management/leaders. Instead, co-workers are left to look out for each other (plus side is we are forced to work well with each other to survive, downside is that we only have each other).

job_title: Labor and Delivery Nurse in Atlanta, GA
pros:
1) The residency program is excellent - you learn so much in the 20-week education and orientation program they've created for L&D. I'm so glad I was hired into this program, I feel like it really fostered my growth into becoming a good nurse.
 
2) The staff hired onto L&D are all team players. You NEED to be a team player to work in this environment - it's how you'll survive busy shifts.

3) I feel like the unit is really welcoming to new nurses - there's no bullying or nurses eating their young here. Northside or the L&D nurses would never tolerate it - everyone is kind and always willing to lend a hand when you need it.

4) After a few years of experience under your belt, there's a lot of opportunities to advance through certifications and promotions on the floor. Career growth opportunity is abundant in the women's health department.
cons:
1) There's no work-life balance. New grads are only allowed to take one week of PTO in the first year of working on L&D. All other nurses are allowed into a complicated "bidding pool" where they can bid on up to 3 weeks of vacation. We're only allowed 4 call-outs per year. It's a confusing process where you need to plan to "bid" on vacation time almost 6 months to a year in advance of the time you end up getting off. I don't think any of the new grad nurses in my residency class were aware of how little PTO we'd be allowed to take. I don't believe this is a Northside issue - but definitely a Labor & Delivery issue.

2) Turnover is kind of high on the floor - I think people get burnt out on the volume of patients we have. There are no "down days" at work at Northside L&D. Just know what you're getting yourself into going in - this is the busiest L&D in the country - and the workload definitely shows it.

cons: Communication is lacking, there needs to be a better way of communicating with team members and management .

review_title: Redundant charting system and too fixated on the wrong things
pros: I can truly say I had the sweetest and most supportive floor ever. I am absolutely going to miss everyone and would not change a thing about the teamwork on the unit (hence the 3 stars). Any problem or concern I had, they were always addressed and handled with the utmost integrity. I came off residency and every single staff member helped me in every way possible (which is not the norm at most hospitals). The hospital itself was brand new and gorgeous. The rooms were so clean and had the greatest views! Also, they worked with your schedule which was so greatly appreciated, they allowed me to work twice a week when studying for the nclex.
cons: The med/surg floor that I applied for, was not as it was described to me. The patients were of a much higher acuity than they were supposed to be (which I guess is due to COVID). Unstable patients were constantly being sent up to our unit, which created a very stressful work environment. On top of that, you had up to 6 patients to worry about and management would bother you for petty things such as your 5 P's or charting your 2-hour pain reassessments. THERE ARE BIGGER THINGS TO WORRY ABOUT SOMETIMES, WHY ARE YOU PRESSING ME FOR NOT ASKING A PATIENT WHAT THEIR GOAL IS FOR TODAY WHEN I HAVE TO GET REPORT FROM 4 OTHER NURSES & GET STARTED ON AN ADMISSION. It seemed like patients were constantly being transferred to ICU and there was no regard for new nurses when patient assignments were being made. The pay wasn't competitive and I feel as though I wasn't fully prepared to be on my own.
